tit.e: "Katsudo Benshi" (A Narrator of The Silent Movie)
tit.cmt: ・セル6・8等で、その日本語の俗称をローマ字で紹介することに鑑み、ここでも「活動弁士」のローマ字表記をあえて併記しておいた方が流れがよい、と考えました。

sen.j: 活動弁士（かつどうべんし）は、活動写真すなわち無声映画（サイレント映画）を上映中に、その内容を語りで表現して解説する専門の職業的解説者。
sen.e: "Katsudo benshi" is a Japanese professional narrator of an old motion picture, or a silent movie, who gives the live narration for the audience.
sen.cmt: ・「活動弁士」は現在も存在する（セル45参照）ので現在形にしています。 ・日本に特有のもの（セル27参照）なので、"Japanese"を補っています。 ・「活動写真」の定訳は発見できませんでしたが「動く写真」という日本語の語感に一番近いのが"motion picture"であろう、と考えました。
sen.e: A katsudo benshi is a Japanese professional narrator of an old motion picture, or a silent movie, who gives live narration to the audience.
A katsudo benshi is a Japanese professional narrator of an old motion picture, or a silent movie, who gives live narration to the audience.

sen.j: 活動写真を弁ずるというところから活動写真弁士（かつどうしゃしんべんし）と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Katsudo benshi is officially called "katsudo shashin benshi" (a narrator of the old motion picture), because he or she narrates "katsudo shashin" (the old motion picture).
Katsudo benshi is officially called "katsudo shashin benshi" (lit. moving picture narrator), because he or she narrates "katsudo shashin" (moving pictures).

sen.e: For short, it is called "katsuben," but this is just the popular name.

sen.j: 日本で映画が初めて公開されたのは、明治29年（1896年）11月25日の神戸神港倶楽部においてであった。
sen.e: It was on November 25, 1869, at Kobe Shinko Club that a movie was released for the first time in Japan.
The first movie to be shown in Japan was on November 25, 1869, at the Kobe Shinko Club.

sen.j: 輸入品のキネトスコープは日本人にとっては全く未知の装置であり、またフィルムもたいへん短いものであったため、映画を興行として成り立たせるためには、機械の説明をして、場を盛り上げる説明者が必要だった。
sen.e: The imported kinetoscope was a completely unknown device for Japanese and the film was very short, so a movie interpreter, explaining the device and livening up the audience, was necessary for making the movie sustainable as a show.

sen.j: 初期の映画はほとんどが無声映画（サイレント映画）であり、作品中では出演者の声や音楽が一切流れなかった。
sen.e: The movies in the early days were mostly the silent ones, so there was no actors' voice nor music in it.
Early movies were mostly the silent, so had no actors' voices or music.

sen.j: 欧米では映画の中に挿入されるセリフや背景解説のショット（図を参照）と伴奏音楽によって上映されていたが、日本では言語や文化背景の相違も影響し、上映する際には口頭で説明することが求められた。
sen.e: In Europe and America, movies had the shots of lines & background briefing on screen (cf. the side figure) and also had the accompaniment, but in Japan, the language, cultural background and other factors different from the West demanded the simultaneous narration.

In Europe and America, movies had the shots of lines and background briefings shown on screen (see image) and also had musical accompaniment, but in Japan, language, cultural background and other factors different from the West meant that simultaneous narration was demanded.

sen.j: 日本は話芸の文化が多彩であり、特に人形浄瑠璃における太夫と三味線、歌舞伎における出語り、写し絵、錦影絵の解説者といったナレーション文化がすでに定着していた。
sen.e: Japan has various kinds of storytelling arts, and in those days, there already existed the established culture of narration, which was shouldered by, for example, "tayu" (a storyteller in "ningyo joruri" [traditional Japanese puppet theater]) accompanied with "shamisen" (the three-stringed Japanese banjo), "degatari" (the musicians who appear on stage of Kabuki [the classical Japanese dance-drama]), and a talker in "utsushie" (also called "nishiki-kagee," a magic lantern picture).

sen.j: そのため、日本においては、映画作品の内容にあわせて台本を書き、上映中に進行にあわせてそれを口演する特殊な職業と文化が出現した。
sen.e: And so, there emerged in Japan the peculiar occupation (& its culture) that he or she wrote a script in accordance with the movie contents, and that he or she told it simultaneously as the movie went.

There therefore emerged in Japan the peculiar occupation (and its culture) that he or she wrote a script in accordance with the movie content, and that he or she spoke it simultaneously as the movie ran.

sen.j: 戦前には娯楽が少ない中で映画がその中心を占め、活動弁士もその状況に応じて活躍するようになり、西村楽天、徳川夢声、大蔵貢、生駒雷遊、國井紫香、静田錦波、谷天郎、山野一郎、牧野周一、伍東宏郎、泉詩郎、里見義郎、松田春翠、大辻司郎のような人気弁士も現れるようになった。
sen.e: Before World War Ⅱ, the movie occupied the center stage of few entertainments, so katsudo benshi became active and there emerged some popular ones, such as Rakuten NISHIMURA, Musei TOKUGAWA, Mitsugu OKURA, Raiyu IKOMA, Shiko KUNII, Kinpa SHIZUTA, Tenro TANI, Ichiro YAMANO, Shuichi MAKINO, Koro GOTO, Shiro IZUMI, Yoshiro SATOMI, Shunsui MATSUDA, and Shiro OTSUJI.

sen.e: So most katsudo benshi were forced to give up their business, and many of them became a professional storyteller (including a comic one), a picture-story show performer, a master of ceremonies, and so on.
